message_1: A sample of radioactive material has a half-life of 3 days. If the initial activity of the sample was 500 Bq, what will be its activity after 9 days?
message_2:
To solve this problem, we can use the formula for radioactive decay:

Activity_final = Activity_initial * (1/2)^(time_elapsed / half_life)

where Activity_final is the activity of the sample after the given time, Activity_initial is the initial activity of the sample, time_elapsed is the time that has passed, and half_life is the half-life of the radioactive material.

In this case, we have:

Activity_initial = 500 Bq
half_life = 3 days
time_elapsed = 9 days

Plugging these values into the formula, we get:

Activity_final = 500 Bq * (1/2)^(9 days / 3 days)

Activity_final = 500 Bq * (1/2)^3

Activity_final = 500 Bq * (1/8)

Activity_final = 62.5 Bq

So, the activity of the radioactive material after 9 days will be 62.5 Bq.
